Highlighted Projects

I have comprehensive experience across the full lifecycle of building AI solutions — from gathering requirements and understanding business needs, to conducting literature research and feasibility studies, through initial development and experimentation, and finally to solution industrialization, deployment, and ongoing monitoring to ensure performance and reliability. Last but not least, I provide documentation, knowledge transfer, and training to ensure team alignment and facilitate smooth adoption.

I use Python as my main programming language, leveraging its extensive ecosystem for rapid development and integration. I rely on Terraform to manage AWS cloud infrastructure, enabling the creation of scalable and cost-efficient solutions. I am also used to working with GitLab CI/CD pipelines and implementing unit testing to ensure code quality and reliability.

I am increasingly moving towards a Full Stack profile, getting familiar with JavaScript and Vue.js.

Learn More

Web application

I created fablens.it with two main goals: to bring together insights and skills I've gained throughout different stages of my career into a single project, and to build something with some social impact.

Fablens is a proof-of-concept web application designed to identify potential discrepancies between satellite imagery and cadastral records in Italy. It combines public satellite photos and cadastral maps using AI and computer vision to detect buildings that may not be officially registered. For more details click here.

About me

The seek of challenge

I am a curious and passionate person who loves to learn new skills. I am daily looking for challenges since the first day of parkour practice. In my mind, it is crystal clear that proficiency comes after hard work and perseverance. This motivation pushes me to give my best and fully commit to what I intend to accomplish, growing from the analysis of both failures and successes.

A solid experience

I started my journey with neural networks applied to cognitive neuroscience in Academia. I then assumed a Data Scientist role at Capgemini Engineering, enhancing my machine learning abilities mainly through computer vision projects; developing cloud skills as a lovely side effect. I then became a freelancer to dedicate all my time to clients more efficiently. In my free time, I enjoy building webapps and crafting software solutions with friends.

I have made this website starting from open source code. Thanks to all the contributors of the Start Bootstrap project.

Geospatial service for insurance premium estimation

The project

The project focused on leveraging geospatial computer vision to develop a geolocated building characteristic extraction service for estimating insurance premiums. Initially, individual microservices were developed, which were later orchestrated into a unified service.

High-level pipeline of the service put into production.

  • Handled MAXAR or geospatial government APIs, Google Geocoding and Street View APIs.
  • Trained, tested and delivered 4 machine learning models: instance segmentation of building rooftops and solar panels [YOLACT]; object detection of building facade elements (like windows, doors, etc.) [YOLOv3]; image classification of buildings facades to categorize their construction material [Efficient-Net].
  • Developed estimation rule-based cv algorithms exploiting ML outputs (e.g., pixel2meter conversion, number of floors estimation, etc.).
  • Industrialized in microservices as Lambda functions, orchestrated by Step Functions, supported by S3 and DynamoDB connections for metadata, images or results storage.
  • When the service was successfully moved into production as a subscription service for several countries I received very positive feedback as the main contributor in this project.

Improved Skills

  • Machine Learning (pytorch, mmdet, YOLACT, YOLO, RtDetrv2)
  • Computer Vision (pillow, opencv, shapely)
  • Geospatial Data (geopandas, MAXAR APIs, Google APIs, WMS APIs)
  • AWS Cloud (S3, Sagemaker, DynamoDB, StepFunctions, Lambda)
  • Python (numpy, matplotlib, pandas)

Anomaly detection from heliborne inspections

The project

The project aimed to detect tiny anomalies in the Italian electricity transmission grid by analyzing high‑resolution aerial photos captured by helicopters. We developed a solution using a cascade of supervised models: first identifying macro‑components, then micro‑components, which were subsequently analyzed by classification models to detect anomalies.

High-level pipeline of the service put into production.

  • Worked in an internal team of 5 data scientist, 3 cloud engineers and 1 PM.
  • Developed computer vision algorithms for the pre-annotation of rare anomalies.
  • Trained, experimented with, and validated three object detection models and one image classification model (YOLOv5).
  • Contributed to building a unified pipeline for processing 50TB cross-account data.
  • Supported the team in utilizing AWS effectively, configuring and managing resources such as IAM, EC2, S3, DynamoDB, Sagemaker.

Improved Skills

  • Machine Learning (pytorch, YOLO, ultralytics)
  • Computer Vision (opencv, shapely)
  • AWS Cloud (S3, EC2, DynamoDB, Lambda, IAM)
  • Python (numpy, matplotlib, pandas)

Brain-inspired model of sequential processing

The project

The model is framed within a Reinforcement Learning framework (an agent interacting with its environment). The agent is equipped with an artificial neural network model (a LSTM) that is capable of learning the transitions through the environment, internally generating possible sequences of actions, and planning the best path to follow in order to obtain a reward.

Schematic representation of the classical reinforcement learning loop. The environment pass state and reward information to the agent at time t. At the same time the agent performs an action that produce effects on the environment. As a response, the environment outputs another pair of state and reward measures at the next state, and the loop can be repeated. The main functions of theta sequences are highlighted in blue (T1 is the encoding function, T2 is the future path evaluation function). Main functions of SWR sequences are highlighted in green (S1 is the training function of the Bi-LSTM network, S2 is the past rewarded path valuation function).

Improved Skills

  • Scientific literature research
  • Reinforcement Learning
  • Bi-LSTM recurrent neural network
  • Object-oriented programming
  • Python (numpy, pytorch, matplotlib)

Useful links

  • The code can be found in my Github repository.
  • The whole model simulates what has been argued to happen in the hippocampal formation of mammal brains. For a review see Olafsdottir et al (2018).
  • The cover picture representing "a brain" is offered by rawpixel.com.

Europeans beliefs on climate change

The project

Climate change is a serious and urgent problem for humankind. Stakes are high and we need to stop it. A crucial step is to gain awareness of the problem, the next step is to actively work for improving the situation. With this analysis I explored the European Social Survey dataset of 2016/2017 to gather some insights on climate change beliefs of many European countries guided by some questions you have probably already asked yourself.

  • Do Europeans actually acknowledge the relevance of climate change?
  • Are there some hidden beliefs that might undermine a fast and efficient problem resolution?
  • Do European countries have different problems and therefore different directions of improvement?
  • Are there apparently unrelated factors that are instead related to climate change beliefs?

Results shows that more than 90% of people acknowledge that the world's climate change is definitely or probably happening. From this group of people not even 45% of them think the climate is changing entirely or mainly due to human activities. Considering just the latter group, slightly more than 50% of them feel a distinct personal responsibility to try to reduce climate change.

Different countries have different response patterns, and therefore different directions of improvement.

Improved Skills

  • Exploratory data analysis
  • Data Cleaning
  • Data Visualization
  • Ordered Logistic Regression
  • Python (pandas, plotly, scipy, statmodels)

Useful links

  • The code can be found in my Github repository.
  • The .csv file is from Pascal Biliem.
  • The data have been collected by the European Social Survey.
  • The cover picture representing "a map" is offered by freepik.com.

Disaster Response Classifier

The project

I have built a ML pipeline able to classify messages sent during disaster events into meaningful classes (e.g., Food, Medical Help, Shelter, etc...).
During emergency situations a lot of people need the support of disaster relief agencies. However, given the overwhelming number of messages it could be hard to filter the relevant messages and to automatically send the message to the suitable organization. That is why a classification pipeline could be a very useful tool.

The app first provides an overview on the training dataset. Then, when a message in inserted as input, it shows all the classes available and highlights the classes related to the message.

Improved Skills

  • Natural Language Processing (preprocessing and feature extraction)
  • Machine Learning Pipeline (model fitting and model selection)
  • Full-stack web app development (server, database, front-end)
  • Python (flask, pandas, plotly, sklearn, sqlalchemy), HTML-JS-CSS (boostrap, jquery), SQL

Useful links

  • The code can be found in my Github repository.
  • Data were made available by Figure Eight Inc.
  • Part of the code was made available by Udacity.
  • The cover picture representing "a book" is offered by Joshua Hoehne.

Analysis Pipeline for Neural Acitity

The project

The research line aimed to study the neural activity in the hippocampal formation of epilepsy patients under a verbal fluency task. My contribution was the development of a pipeline of integration, pre-processing and analysis of four types of data: anatomical, electrophysiological, speech, word embeddings.

For each patient four types of data were available. A) Anatomical data such as T1 scans, white matter and hippocampal formation segmentation, and electrodes labels. B) Electrophysiological data coming from an average of 64 channels recording for aproximately 25 minutes. C) Speech data of patients voice recorded while mentioning aloud the highest number of animal names as possible. D) FastText word embeddings freely available online.

Improved Skills

  • Data Integration
  • Data Cleaning and Preprocessing
  • Speech Recognition and Segmentation
  • Dimensionality Reduction analysis (PCA)
  • Time Frequency analysis (fft, morelet-wavelet)
  • Slicing software (Slicer3D)

Useful links

  • The project is part of a research line at BottiniLab
  • The project is made in collaboration with Ospedale Niguarda .
  • The affiliate university is University of Trento.

[Exercise] Churned User Prediction

The project

I have worked with PySpark to analyze a log of user activities interacting with a digital music service. The goal is to predict which users are about to cancel their subscription, aiming to keeping them as customers providing them extra attentions.

I performed data cleaning, exploratory data analysis, feature engineering and modeling. The whole project is very simple and it is supposed to be an excuse to exercise with pySpark.

Besides that, the modeling section has reserved a nice problem to face:

The model is biased toward predicting users as active almost every time, leading to a big amount of false negatives and an overall weak prediction performance.

This is due to the class imbalance problem. In the dataset the number of active users were 2.5x the number of churn users. This is an intriguing problem to solve, yet some methods exists to mitigate the problem (downsampling / upsampling tecniques).

The aim of this work was to familiarize with PySpark logic and syntax. However, there are a lot of improvements that can start from here and take this project to another level: addressing the class imbalance problem more seriously, using a bigger dataset, leaning against a cloud computing service to exploit all the power of spark with big data, building a web application to deploy the model with a comfortable user interface, and much more.

I am currently diving into AWS. I'm planning to come back to this project in the near future to perform some of the improvements mentioned above.

Improved Skills

  • ETL
  • Feature Engineering
  • Python (PySkark)

Useful links

  • The code can be found in my Github repository.
  • The cover picture representing "a network" is offered by rawpixel.com

[Exercise] IMB articles recommendation

The project

I have analyzed the interactions between users and articles of the IBM Watson Studio platform. The goal was to build a recommendation system: to suggest users some articles they might like and they have not seen already.

The Dataset was provided by IBM and manily consisted in a log of interactions between users and articles. There are many ways to provide recommendations, and I took this project as an exercise to try serveral ones on the same data.

  • Rank-Based: recommend the most popular articles.
  • User-Based Collaborative Filtering: recommend articles popular among similar users.
  • Matrix Factorization: decompose a user-article matrix and extract the latent factors that help to predict which are the best recommendations.

Improved Skills

  • ETL
  • Recommendation Systems
  • Python (pandas, numpy)

Useful links

  • The code can be found in my Github repository.
  • The cover picture representing "5 stars" is offered by DilokaStudio
